lucaa - (10:41): hi guys  
sdumitriu - (10:42): Hi girl  
lucaa - (10:43): I'm handling now the rights for the annotations application, and I need a little advice.  
lucaa - (10:43): I have the multiple layers: 2 IO services, implemented on xwiki model that handles storage of data (documents & annotations), an annotation service that aggregates these IO services and provides the annotations specific functionalities, a rest service to access this with ajax and a velocity bridge to expose the annotation service to velo scripting  
lucaa - (10:43): at which level should I do rights checking?  
lucaa - (10:46): I see 3 options:  
lucaa - (10:46): 1/ at IO service level, to make sure that the service doesn't provide data to unauthorized users  (I would be checking against XWikiContext.getUser)  
lucaa - (10:46): 2/ at AnnotationService level: but this would make the service depend on the context (and the user on the context)  
lucaa - (10:46): 3/ at velocity bridge & rest service level, which would check rights before calling the ANnotationService  
jvdrean joined #xwiki at 10:51  
lucaa - (10:57): sdumitriu: ideas?  
sdumitriu - (10:58): Hm...  
sdumitriu - (10:58): Currently the core-core does not do right checks  
sdumitriu - (10:58): Those are either in the API or in the web actions  
lucaa - (10:59): now, I'd be for solution no 3/ since I think it's the way we do it in the wiki...  
lucaa - (10:59): yes, my thoughts exactly  
sdumitriu - (10:59): I'd go for either 2 or 3  
sdumitriu - (10:59): For 2, can't you use the execution context?  
lucaa - (11:00): the way REST service does it for the standard resources is to get the api.XWiki and get a document from there, which is right-checking API  
lucaa - (11:01): well, for 2 or 3 I think I would be defining an AnnotationRightsService (:( overenineering) to provide rights checking implementation specific to annotations...  
lucaa - (11:01): and I'd implement AnnnotationRightService using the XWiki model  
lucaa - (11:02): (since AnnotationService is an abstraction over XWiki storage or other type of storage, I wouldn't like to put a dep of the xwiki rights service in there...)  
lucaa - (11:03): but it's a good q, could I use \_just\_ the execution context to get rights without dep on old core?  
sdumitriu - (11:03): Rights, no  
sdumitriu - (11:03): Just the user  
sdumitriu - (11:03): And only after changing the core  
sdumitriu - (11:03): Since the user is not stored in the underlying map  
lucaa - (11:03): :)  
lucaa - (11:04): so answer is no  
sdumitriu - (11:04): The answer is yes with ammendments  
lucaa - (11:04): :)  
sdumitriu - (11:04): Do you know the joke about Ivan who won a brand new car?  
lucaa - (11:04): I think I do... but I'd love to hear it again  
sdumitriu - (11:06): Call on Radio Erevan: Is it true that Ivan Ivanovich won a brand new car?  
sdumitriu - (11:06): Radio host: Yes, that is true, but it wasn't Ivan Ivanovich, but Alex Alexeyevich, it wasn't a car, but a bike, and he didn't win it, it was stolen from him  
lucaa - (11:06): yes, yes, always a good laugh  
lucaa - (11:07): btw devs, new annotation demo on the incubator, working fine on all browsers!!! enjoy and please feedback on how it feels to use (there's a thread for that on the ml)  
sdumitriu - (11:07): So yes, you can use the execution context if you really want  
lucaa - (11:07): except I don't get the value from the EC, I put it :)  
sdumitriu - (11:07): Right  
lucaa - (11:08): do we have a standard practice for the rights checking in extensions?  
lucaa - (11:08): API level, storage level?  
lucaa - (11:11): I'm looking at the plugins code, and I see the idea is to do rights checking at PluginApi level  
arkub joined #xwiki at 11:12  
lucaa - (11:12): which is API level, in my case meaning either 3/ or an extrawrapper on top of AnnotationService  
lucaa - (11:16): but is it safe to have the AnnotationService depend on the context (if I could use the EC)? I mean, is there any situation where the context would be void and I would still get to call the service, etc? I don't see a direct connection between the service and a context...
